topics.title: Creative Destruction: Innovation's Brutal Engine

hook.text: Kodak invented the digital camera in 1975, then buried it to protect film sales.

buildup.text: Joseph Schumpeter coined 'creative destruction': new innovations destroy old industries. Cars replaced horses.

discovery.text: Creative destruction is capitalism's engine.

twist.text: The destruction is real. Blockbuster employed 84,000 people. Netflix employs 13,000 and serves 100x more customers.

climax.text: Creative destruction is simultaneously capitalism's greatest feature and its cruelest.

punchline.text: Progress means building the future on the rubble of someone's career.

quiz.question: What happened when Kodak invented the digital camera in 1975?
options: They suppressed it to protect film profits and eventually went bankrupt when others commercialized digital photography
Digital cameras failed in the market

topics.title: Moore's Law: The Engine of Exponential Growth

hook.text: In 1965, Gordon Moore predicted transistor density would double every two years.

buildup.text: Moore's Law isn't physics â€” it's economics. Chipmakers invest to double performance because the market rewards it.

discovery.text: A smartphone today has more computing power than NASA used to land on the moon.

twist.text: Moore's Law is slowing. Transistors are approaching atomic scale.

climax.text: Moore's Law taught tech companies to plan for exponential improvement.

punchline.text: For 60 years, computers got twice as powerful every two years.

quiz.question: Why is Moore's Law described as economics rather than physics?
options: It only applies to economic models
Chipmakers invest to meet the prediction because the market rewards doubling performance â€” it's a self-fulfilling prophecy

topics.title: Productivity Paradox: Computers Everywhere Except the Statistics

hook.text: Robert Solow wrote in 1987: 'You can see the computer age everywhere but in the productivity statistics.

buildup.text: The productivity paradox: massive technology investment should boost output per worker.

discovery.text: One explanation: technology takes decades to transform work.

twist.text: Another explanation: GDP mismeasures digital value.

climax.text: The productivity paradox reveals that our economic measurements were designed for a factory age.

punchline.text: Maybe technology IS making us richer. We're just measuring wrong.

quiz.question: Why might GDP understate the value of digital technology?
options: Free services like Google Search and Wikipedia provide enormous consumer value that isn't captured by GDP measurements

topics.title: Intellectual Property: Ideas as Property

hook.text: A pill costs $0.10 to manufacture and $2 billion to develop. Without patents, the copycat sells it for $0.

buildup.text: Patents grant a temporary monopoly: 20 years to be the sole seller.

discovery.text: The patent system worked well for physical inventions.

twist.text: Patent trolls â€” companies that own patents but make nothing â€” sue real innovators.

climax.text: IP protection is a balancing act: too little and nobody invests; too much and nobody can build.

punchline.text: Intellectual property is meant to reward creators.

quiz.question: What is the economic tradeoff of patent protection?
options: Higher prices today (monopoly period) fund the research that creates innovations everyone eventually benefits from

topics.title: S-Curves: Why New Technologies Start Slow and Finish Fast

hook.text: The internet had 10 million users in 1995 and 5 billion by 2023.

buildup.text: Technology adoption follows an S-curve: slow start as early adopters tinker.

discovery.text: Cars, electricity, telephones, smartphones â€” every transformative technology followed the same S-curve.

twist.text: Companies die when they confuse the slow start for failure.

climax.text: S-curves explain why predictions about technology are always wrong.

punchline.text: Every revolution looks like a toy in the beginning and obvious in hindsight.

quiz.question: Why do people consistently underestimate new technologies?
options: The S-curve starts slow, making linear thinkers miss the explosive growth phase that follows

topics.title: Zero Marginal Cost: When Copies Are Free

hook.text: It costs Spotify $0 to stream a song to one more listener.

buildup.text: Physical goods have marginal costs â€” each extra unit costs materials and labor. Digital goods don't.

discovery.text: Zero marginal cost creates winner-take-all markets.

twist.text: If marginal cost is zero, competitive pricing should be zero â€” free.

climax.text: Zero marginal cost upends traditional economics.

punchline.text: In the digital economy, the product is free. You're paying with something else.

quiz.question: Why does zero marginal cost lead to 'free' digital products?
options: When each additional copy costs nothing, competition drives prices toward zero, forcing business models based on ads or data

topics.title: The Attention Economy: Your Eyeballs Are the Product

hook.text: You pay nothing for Google, Instagram, or TikTok. But these companies are worth trillions.

buildup.text: Herbert Simon predicted it in 1971: 'A wealth of information creates a poverty of attention.

discovery.text: Tech companies optimize for engagement â€” the time you spend scrolling.

twist.text: The attention economy creates a misalignment: what keeps you scrolling isn't what makes you happy.

climax.text: When attention is the product, the economic incentive is to make everything addictive.

punchline.text: If you're not paying for the product, your brain is the product.

quiz.question: What is the core misalignment in the attention economy?
options: What keeps users engaged (outrage, FOMO) isn't what makes them happy â€” engagement optimization often increases anxiety

topics.title: Data as Capital: The New Oil

hook.text: Google knows what you search. Amazon knows what you buy. Facebook knows who you love.

buildup.text: Data is the raw material of AI, targeted advertising, and personalization.

discovery.text: Data exhibits increasing returns: more data â†’ better AI â†’ better products â†’ more users â†’ more data.

twist.text: Unlike oil, data isn't depleted when used.

climax.text: Data is capital that users create for free and companies monetize forever.

punchline.text: You generate the data. They collect the profits. And nobody asked permission.

quiz.question: Why does data create monopolistic advantages?
options: More data improves AI which attracts more users who generate more data â€” a self-reinforcing cycle that's hard to break
Only one company can collect data

topics.title: Two-Sided Markets: Why Uber Loses Money and Doesn't Care

hook.text: Uber lost $31 billion in its first decade. Investors kept funding it.

buildup.text: Two-sided markets connect two groups: riders and drivers, buyers and sellers, developers and users.

discovery.text: The chicken-and-egg problem: riders won't join without drivers; drivers won't join without riders.

twist.text: Once both sides are locked in, the platform raises prices and cuts subsidies.

climax.text: Two-sided markets naturally tip toward monopoly. Once one platform has both sides, switching costs trap everyone.

punchline.text: When a company loses billions to gain customers, it's not being generous.

quiz.question: Why did Uber subsidize rides at a loss for years?
options: To solve the chicken-and-egg problem and capture both sides of the market before raising prices
They never planned to make money

topics.title: The Long Tail: How the Internet Destroyed the Blockbuster Model

hook.text: A physical bookstore stocks 100,000 titles. Amazon stocks 33 million.

buildup.text: Chris Anderson's Long Tail: when distribution costs drop to zero, niche products become viable.

discovery.text: Spotify has 100 million songs. The bottom 80% are played rarely.

twist.text: But the long tail hasn't replaced hits â€” it's amplified them. Top 1% of artists earn 80% of Spotify revenue.

climax.text: The internet created a paradox: infinite variety AND extreme concentration.

punchline.text: The internet gave everyone a shelf. It also gave the bestsellers a bigger store.

quiz.question: What paradox did the Long Tail create in practice?
options: The internet enabled infinite variety but also amplified concentration â€” top artists earn more while niche creators struggle

topics.title: Network Effects: Why Size Is Power

hook.text: The first fax machine was worthless â€” nobody else had one.

buildup.text: Network effects: a product becomes more valuable as more people use it.

discovery.text: Metcalfe's Law: a network's value grows proportionally to the square of its users.

twist.text: Network effects can work in reverse. Users leave MySpace for Facebook; more users leave because their friends left.

climax.text: Network effects explain why tech markets tip toward monopoly.

punchline.text: In networks, the rich get richer â€” not because they're better.

quiz.question: What makes network effects so powerful in creating monopolies?
options: Each new user makes the product more valuable for all existing users, creating a self-reinforcing advantage that's hard to compete against
Only one company can create networks

topics.title: Platform Lock-In: The Golden Cage

hook.text: Switching from iPhone to Android means losing your iMessage group chats, app purchases, and 10 years of photos.

buildup.text: Lock-in: when switching costs are so high that users stay even when alternatives are better.

discovery.text: Amazon's ecosystem â€” Prime, Alexa, Kindle, Ring â€” creates cross-product lock-in.

twist.text: Lock-in isn't accidental â€” it's designed.

climax.text: Platform lock-in transfers power from users to platforms.

punchline.text: The easiest platform to join is the hardest to leave. That's not a coincidence.

quiz.question: Why do companies deliberately increase switching costs?
options: High switching costs trap users, reducing competition and allowing the platform to extract more value from captive users

topics.title: The Gig Economy: Flexibility or Exploitation?

hook.text: Uber calls drivers 'independent contractors.

buildup.text: The gig economy: platforms match workers with tasks.

discovery.text: 70 million Americans did gig work in 2023. For some, it's freedom.

twist.text: The algorithm is the boss. It sets prices, assigns work, and can 'deactivate' you without explanation or appeal.

climax.text: The gig economy transfers risk from companies to workers.

punchline.text: Be your own boss â€” as long as you do exactly what the algorithm says.

quiz.question: How does the gig economy shift risk between companies and workers?
options: Platforms transfer risk to workers by classifying them as contractors, avoiding benefits and minimum wage obligations

topics.title: Surveillance Capitalism: Predicting and Shaping Your Behavior

hook.text: Google doesn't just predict what you'll search.

buildup.text: Shoshana Zuboff coined 'surveillance capitalism'.

discovery.text: Your behavioral surplus â€” data beyond what's needed for the service â€” is extracted, analyzed, and sold.

twist.text: Prediction isn't enough. Platforms now shape behavior.

climax.text: Surveillance capitalism turns human experience into a commodity.

punchline.text: They're not just watching what you do. They're deciding what you'll do next.

quiz.question: What makes surveillance capitalism different from traditional advertising?
options: It doesn't just predict behavior â€” it actively shapes behavior through algorithmic nudges, turning human experience into a tradeable commodity

topics.title: Winner-Take-All: Why Only Five Companies Dominate Tech

hook.text: Apple, Microsoft, Google, Amazon, and Meta are worth more than the entire stock markets of most countries.

buildup.text: Three forces create tech monopolies: network effects (users attract users), economies of scale (zero marginal cost).

discovery.text: Each force is self-reinforcing, and combined they're nearly unbreakable.

twist.text: History suggests monopolies eventually fall â€” but tech monopolies may be different.

climax.text: Tech concentration creates efficiency but concentrates power, wealth.

punchline.text: Five companies control the digital world. Is that efficiency or a problem?

quiz.question: What three forces create tech monopolies?
options: Network effects, zero marginal cost economies of scale, and data-driven AI advantages that are each self-reinforcing

topics.title: Automation Anxiety: Will Robots Take Your Job?

hook.text: A 2013 Oxford study predicted 47% of US jobs could be automated within 20 years.

buildup.text: Automation fear is ancient. Luddites smashed textile machines in 1811. ATMs were supposed to kill bank tellers.

discovery.text: The 'lump of labor fallacy': assuming there's a fixed amount of work.

twist.text: But AI is different from past automation.

climax.text: History says automation creates more jobs than it destroys. But history has never seen machines that think.

punchline.text: Every generation fears machines will replace them.

quiz.question: Why might AI automation be different from previous waves of automation?
options: AI threatens cognitive and creative jobs that previous automation waves left untouched â€” tasks requiring thinking, not just physical labor

topics.title: The Skill Premium: How Technology Splits the Labor Market

hook.text: Since 1980, wages for college graduates rose 25%. Wages for high school graduates fell 15%.

buildup.text: Technology complements high-skill workers: AI helps programmers code faster, Excel helps analysts analyze more.

discovery.text: David Autor found the 'hollowing out' of middle-skill jobs.

twist.text: The polarization creates a barbell economy.

climax.text: Technology doesn't eliminate work. It redistributes it.

punchline.text: Technology is great for workers â€” as long as they already have the right skills.

quiz.question: What is the 'hollowing out' of the labor market?
options: Routine middle-skill jobs are automated while high-skill and hard-to-automate low-skill jobs both grow, eliminating the middle class

topics.title: Remote Work Revolution: Geography Unshackled

hook.text: Before COVID, 5% of work was remote. In 2023, 30% of work is hybrid or remote.

buildup.text: Remote work decouples jobs from geography. A programmer in Boise competes with one in Bangalore.

discovery.text: Studies show remote workers are equally or more productive. Commuting wastes 200+ hours per year.

twist.text: But remote work threatens urban economies.

climax.text: Remote work redistributes economic activity from expensive cities to everywhere else.

punchline.text: COVID didn't invent remote work. It removed the last excuse not to try it.

quiz.question: How does remote work affect geographic inequality?
options: It redistributes economic activity from expensive urban centers to smaller cities and rural areas worldwide

topics.title: AI and the Future of Work: Complement or Replacement?

hook.text: ChatGPT can write legal briefs, code software, and diagnose diseases. But lawyers, programmers, and doctors still exist.

buildup.text: Will AI complement human work (making workers more productive) or substitute it (replacing workers entirely)?

discovery.text: History suggests complement: ATMs made bank tellers focus on sales, not cash counting.

twist.text: But generative AI is different: it performs the creative, cognitive tasks that were supposed to be automation-proof.

climax.text: The most likely outcome: AI transforms every job rather than eliminating them.

punchline.text: AI won't replace you. Someone using AI will.

quiz.question: Why is generative AI different from previous automation waves?
options: It can perform creative and cognitive tasks â€” writing, coding, art â€” that were previously considered uniquely human and automation-proof

topics.title: Antitrust in Tech: Breaking Up Is Hard to Do

hook.text: The US broke up Standard Oil in 1911 and AT&T in 1984. Now Google, Apple, Amazon, and Meta face antitrust suits.

buildup.text: Traditional antitrust focused on consumer harm: monopolies raise prices. But Big Tech often offers free products.

discovery.text: The new antitrust thinking: harm isn't just higher prices.

twist.text: Breaking up tech companies might backfire.

climax.text: Tech antitrust requires new economic thinking.

punchline.text: Antitrust law was built for a world of prices.

quiz.question: Why is traditional antitrust law difficult to apply to tech companies?
options: Many tech products are free, making traditional price-based consumer harm analysis inadequate
Tech companies always follow the rules

topics.title: The Digital Divide: When Technology Deepens Inequality

hook.text: During COVID, millions of US students couldn't attend online school.

buildup.text: The digital divide: unequal access to technology, broadband, and digital skills. 2.

discovery.text: Digital exclusion compounds existing inequality.

twist.text: Even in rich countries, the divide is deep. Rural America has slower internet than many developing nations.

climax.text: Technology that could be the great equalizer instead becomes the great amplifier.

punchline.text: The internet can lift everyone. But only if everyone can get on.

quiz.question: How does the digital divide compound existing inequality?
options: Those without internet access are excluded from jobs, education, healthcare, and government services that increasingly require digital connectivity

topics.title: Tech Taxation: The Impossible Challenge

hook.text: Amazon earned $35 billion in profit in 2023 and paid an effective tax rate of 11%.

buildup.text: Tech companies exploit international tax rules: book profits in low-tax Ireland, costs in high-tax countries.

discovery.text: The 'Double Irish Dutch Sandwich' allowed Google to route profits through Ireland, Netherlands, and Bermuda â€” paying 2.

twist.text: In 2021, 136 countries agreed to a 15% minimum corporate tax.

climax.text: Taxing digital companies challenges the fundamental assumption of tax law: that companies exist in a physical place.

punchline.text: You can't tax what you can't locate. Digital companies live in the cloud.

quiz.question: Why are tech companies particularly difficult to tax?
options: Digital companies can book profits in any jurisdiction since they have no fixed physical presence, exploiting gaps in international tax law

topics.title: Cryptocurrency Economics: Money Without Governments

hook.text: Bitcoin hit $69,000 in 2021, crashed to $16,000.

buildup.text: Cryptocurrency: money created by code, secured by cryptography, and governed by no government.

discovery.text: Bitcoin's fixed supply (21 million coins) mimics gold's scarcity.

twist.text: Bitcoin uses more electricity than Argentina. Its price is driven by speculation, not adoption.

climax.text: Crypto's economic innovation is real: programmable money, decentralized finance, borderless transfers.

punchline.text: Crypto asked: what if money didn't need governments? The answer is still.

quiz.question: What is the core economic innovation of cryptocurrency?
options: Enabling programmable, decentralized money that can be transferred borderlessly without requiring trust in any institution

topics.title: AI Economics: The $15 Trillion Question

hook.text: PwC estimates AI will add $15.7 trillion to the global economy by 2030. That's more than the current GDP of China.

buildup.text: AI reduces costs, automates decisions, and creates new products.

discovery.text: AI's economic value concentrates in companies with data and talent. The US and China control 90% of AI investment.

twist.text: If AI substitutes labor at scale, economic output rises but wages fall. GDP grows while workers suffer.

climax.text: AI is the most consequential economic technology since industrialization.

punchline.text: AI will create trillions in value. The only question is: for whom?

quiz.question: What risk does AI pose to the economy even if it increases total output?
options: GDP can grow while wages fall if AI substitutes labor, concentrating gains among capital owners while workers suffer

topics.title: The Singularity Economy: What Happens When Machines Are Smarter?

hook.text: If a machine can do everything a human can â€” but faster, cheaper, and better.

buildup.text: The technological singularity: the hypothetical point where AI surpasses human intelligence and improves itself.

discovery.text: In a post-labor economy, traditional economics â€” built on scarcity of labor and capital â€” collapses.

twist.text: Keynes predicted that by 2030 we'd work 15-hour weeks. He was right about productivity growth but wrong about work.

climax.text: The singularity economy may never arrive.

punchline.text: The question isn't whether machines will be smarter.

quiz.question: Why does the concept of a 'singularity economy' challenge traditional economics?
options: It would make everyone equally wealthy
If AI provides both labor and capital, the fundamental scarcity assumptions underlying economics collapse

topics.title: Green Tech Economics: Can Innovation Save the Planet?

hook.text: Solar energy costs dropped 90% in a decade. Wind energy is now cheaper than coal in most of the world.

buildup.text: Green tech follows learning curves: every doubling of solar panel production drops costs by 20%.

discovery.text: The energy transition is now economically inevitable.

twist.text: The transition creates losers: fossil fuel workers, oil-rich nations, and industries built on carbon.

climax.text: Green technology shows that innovation can align environmental and economic interests.

punchline.text: The technology to save the planet already exists. The economics work.

quiz.question: Why has the energy transition become economically inevitable?
options: Learning curves and scale have made renewables cheaper than fossil fuels in most applications

topics.title: The Productivity J-Curve: Why New Tech Slows You Down First

hook.text: Companies that adopt AI see productivity drop initially. Workers spend months learning new tools before output rises.

buildup.text: The J-curve: new technology requires reorganization, retraining, and experimentation before gains appear.

discovery.text: Electricity took 30 years to boost productivity. Factories had to be completely redesigned to exploit electric motors.

twist.text: Companies that bail out during the dip miss the payoff. Those who persist through the valley gain lasting advantages.

climax.text: The J-curve explains why tech investments look wasteful at first and transformative later.

punchline.text: Every revolution looks like a mistake before it looks like progress.

quiz.question: What is the productivity J-curve?
options: Productivity always increases with new tech
New technology causes a temporary productivity dip before gains
Technology has no effect on productivity

topics.title: Net Neutrality: Should All Data Be Equal?

hook.text: What if your internet provider could slow Netflix to sell you its own streaming service? Net neutrality prevents.

buildup.text: Net neutrality: all internet traffic should be treated equally.

discovery.text: Without neutrality, ISPs become gatekeepers who pick winners. Startups that can't pay for fast lanes can't compete.

twist.text: ISPs argue paid prioritization funds network investment. Why should Netflix traffic be free when it uses 15% of all.

climax.text: Net neutrality is a fight over who controls the internet's economics: platforms, ISPs, or users.

punchline.text: Net neutrality asks a simple question: is the internet a utility or a product?

quiz.question: What does net neutrality require?
options: Internet providers must charge everyone the same price
All internet traffic must be treated equally

topics.title: Open Source Economics: Free Labor That Creates Billions

hook.text: Linux powers 96% of the world's servers. It was built by volunteers working for free.

buildup.text: Open source: software whose code is freely shared, modified, and distributed. It defies economics.

discovery.text: Developers contribute for reputation, skill-building, and career advancement.

twist.text: Big Tech profits enormously from open source but contributes unevenly.

climax.text: Open source proves that collaboration can outperform competition.

punchline.text: The most valuable software in the world was built for free â€” and nobody owns it.

quiz.question: Why do developers contribute to open source for free?
options: For reputation, skills, and career advancement
They don't know the code has value

topics.title: The Metaverse Economy: Virtual Worlds, Real Money

hook.text: A plot of virtual land in Decentraland sold for $2.4 million. Nothing physical changed hands. The buyer owns pixels.

buildup.text: Virtual economies now generate real value.

discovery.text: Economists study virtual worlds as test labs.

twist.text: Most metaverse investments crashed after the hype. Virtual real estate lost 90% of its value.

climax.text: Virtual economies reveal that value is social agreement.

punchline.text: In virtual worlds, the economics are real. Only the land is fake.

quiz.question: Why do economists study virtual game economies?
options: Games are more important than real economies
They serve as test labs for economic theories
Virtual money is replacing real money
